text:
Hi, this is David from MinuteEarth. 87 
double espressos are enough to kill you;

drink them all at once, and all that caffeine will 
short out your heart and stop it from beating.

Yet coffee shops are filled with plenty of 
not-dead people who have downed hundreds of

cups of coffee over their lifetimes. Here’s why:
You can think of your tolerance for caffeine – or

any substance, really – as a bathtub; that tub 
holds the amount of that substance that can

circulate in your bloodstream safely at a given 
time. The more of that substance you take in,

the more the tub fills up - and the more effects 
you might feel, like the jitters from a series of

double espressos. But your body will keep humming 
along. That is, until the tub overflows…at that

point, the concentration of the substance in 
your bloodstream gets too high, and you’ll die.

Luckily for us caffeine lovers, like real 
bathtubs, our body’s poison tubs can drain.

As your body excretes potential poisons through 
pee and poop, or chemically converts them into

harmless - or even useful - compounds, the level 
of a substance in the hypothetical tub lowers.

Caffeine, for instance, gets metabolized by 
the liver into a buffet of organic molecules.

And it happens fast – the caffeine in one of 
those double espressos will drain from your

tub in a matter of hours. That's why you can drink 
pretty much as much caffeine as you want, as long

as you space it out. Cyanide - surprisingly - also 
drains quickly, as your body speedily converts it

to vitamin B12. So even though your cyanide tub 
is tiny, eating a few cyanide-packed apple seeds

every day is perfectly safe. Lead, on the other 
hand, leaves the body really slowly because it

gets stored in bones. So even though your lead tub 
isn’t tiny, since pretty much every lead exposure

throughout your life slowly inches the level in 
the tub upwards, it’s more likely to overflow.

These tubs exist for pretty much every 
substance we ingest - even water. If

you manage to guzzle more than 6 liters at 
once, your body’s water tub will overflow;

all that water will cause your cells to swell 
beyond repair. Luckily, that tub empties super

fast; not only does your body use water for 
pretty much every biological process, you can

also pee out any extra water within minutes. 
Now that’s what I call draining the main vein.

We love coming up with groan-inducing puns 
for our videos, and as we’ve expanded our

channel into other languages, it’s been 
awesome to see how those puns translate.

In order to truly appreciate them, though, 
I need something more than poorly-remembered

highschool Spanish, so I’ve started using this 
video’s sponsor, Babbel, to hone my skills.

The great thing about Babbel is that it teaches 
you using real life situations and conversations.

By practicing just 15 minutes a day for 3 
weeks, I’ve managed to go from mumbling “hola”

to our resident Spaniard Arcadi to saying 
things like: “¿Qué hace el pez perezoso?

Nada.” To start conversing - and joking 
- in a new language today - and get 65%

off an annual subscription. Click on the 
link in the description. ¡Gracias Babbel!
